ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend the course to any student of American history, mostly because the course proved so productive. I worked hard, but I made a lot of progress toward understanding the period of history, the historiography of that period, the discipline of history. I also made a lot of progress toward my reading for orals. I don't know how I could summarize it: I guess the word I used above, "productive," captures my feeling well. So does "enjoyable."
A truly excellent class. The readings were great; the seminar was enjoyable and interesting; and Prof. Dubcovsky-Joseph was a pleasure to work with.
This is a fantastic course for anybody interested in researching and/or teaching early American history.
I would absolutely recommend HIST707 (and have already done so).
Yes -- I learned more than I ever thought was possible in the course of a semester.
I would recommend this class to anyone interested in learning more about early America.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I may decide to do my own work in the period as a result of this course. If I don't, the course has certainly introduced me to the questions I'll need to consider as I approach American history in any period.
The books and the articles gave me a broad view of the literature on early America, which will be incredibly helpful when preparing for orals.

Alejandra spoke quite often about subjects like syllabus creation, book writing and turning a dissertation into a book, and teaching. I found these brief discussions, and the Skype sessions with other professors, helpful in understanding the profession and the field. This course was helpful in helping me understand a chronological period that precedes my area of interest.
